awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Approximations for the Solution and Uncertainty Analysis of Data-Intensive Inverse Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
In scientific fields ranging from geophysics and atmospheric science to medical imaging and network communication, data are being generated at remarkable rates. Such data are typically indirectly related to quantities of interest and the data sets are in many cases dynamically growing. Extracting desired information from these data then requires the solution of very large data-intensive inverse problems, perhaps repeatedly and in real time. The computational challenges of obtaining such a solution are compounded by the demands of validation and uncertainty analysis, which can easily become computationally prohibitive. This project will develop mathematical/statistical methods and computational tools for the solution of data-intensive inverse problems. The core of this approach is a stochastic reformulation of such problems that aims to significantly reduce the computational costs while adapting to modern hardware architectures.

A framework will be developed to address the challenges arising at the interface between big data, inverse problems, data analysis, and uncertainty quantification.  First, randomized methods for the solution of linear and nonlinear inverse problems will be introduced, so that efficient stochastic optimization methods can be used to overcome the hardware limitations of current algorithms and to generate solutions and uncertainty assessments in near-real time. New theory and scalable methods will be developed within the stochastic framework, thereby ensuring solution accuracy, reliability, and robustness. Second, advanced tools will be developed for model validation, error analysis, and uncertainty quantification. By partnering with application scientists (e.g., in atmospheric remote sensing), methods developed in this project will be of immediate practical utility for scientists and engineers.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to develop mathematical and statistical methods and computational tools for the solution and uncertainty analysis of data-intensive inverse problems. A core element of this approach is a stochastic reformulation of such problems, tightly integrated with regularization methods and stochastic optimization, that aims to significantly reduce the computational costs of inversion and uncertainty assessment while adapting to modern hardware architectures. Another important element was to advance and exploit links between stochastic optimization, data reduction, and optimal experimental design.

Intellectual Merit. This project produced a number of important advances in large-scale inverse problems and optimal experimental design. We developed new adaptive methods for learning the discretizations of expensive forward models in inverse problems; here, the key novelty was that aspects of the discretization are learned from the data themselves, in a Bayesian statistical formulation. We also developed and analyzed Markov chain Monte Carlo samplers for Bayesian inverse problems that exploit sparse conditional independence structure, and established conditions under which posterior sampling in an appropriately partitioned problem has a convergence rate that is independent of dimension. Finally, in the setting of optimal experimental design, we proposed and analyzed new batch greedy heuristics for cardinality constrained maximization of non-submodular design criteria, considering both the standard greedy paradigm and its distributed and stochastic greedy variants. Here we established theoretical guarantees applicable to common settings such as Bayesian linear inverse problems, and also re-interpreted classical greedy algorithms using the minorized-maximize principle, enabling the use of other modular bounds.

Broader Impacts. The computational approaches developed and analyzed in this project have broad applicability to inverse problems appearing in the geosciences, imaging, signal processing, and beyond. To realize this impact and ensure feedback from applications to methodology, we have: (1) applied our algorithms to optimal experimental design problems arising in climate monitoring and (2) pursued a collaboration with research scientists at the Caltech/NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory on inverse problems arising in earth remote sensing. The mathematical and computational ideas developed in this work enabled more principled and scalable solution methods to inverse problems arising in both of these application domains. This award has also enabled the training of undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers at MIT.
